body_html: functor::PadInput will still be needed in some cases. cudnn only allows equal padding on both sides. It is possible to sometimes allow the left-padding to be slightly larger than the right-padding with cudnn, so in some cases, we might not need functor::PadInput when the padding is [3, 2]. But, when I measured the performance of tf_cnn_benchmarks with explicit padding, I didn't implement that optimization, and always would call functor::PadInput when the left-padding was larger than the right-padding.

body: `functor::PadInput` will still be needed in some cases. cudnn only allows equal padding on both sides. It is possible to sometimes allow the left-padding to be slightly larger than the right-padding with cudnn, so in some cases, we might not need `functor::PadInput` when the padding is [3, 2]. But, when I measured the performance of `tf_cnn_benchmarks` with explicit padding, I didn't implement that optimization, and always would call `functor::PadInput` when the left-padding was larger than the right-padding.
